Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Equilibria in Health Exchanges: Adverse Selection, Reclassification Risk, and Dynamic Contracting

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
Health insurance markets are subject to a variety of regulations driven by efficiency and equity provision. The Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (PPACA) proposes the use of exchanges; markets where insurers offer yearly policies subject to several pricing rules. Despite the substantial public discussion of health exchanges, there has been little formal analysis of the likely outcomes and welfare impact of alternative designs. The goal of this project is model of insurer competition in a regulated marketplace in order to investigate both theoretically and empirically the functioning of exchanges.

The PIs develop a model of an insurance exchange building on the models of Rothschild and Stiglitz (1976), Wilson (1977), Miyazaki (1977) and Riley (1985). They propose to investigate the properties of equilibria in exchanges and present an algorithm to find equilibria using a population and their estimated distributions of health risk and preferences. The PIs use detailed information on individual-level health plan choices and health claims from a large firm to simulate an exchange. Preferences are recovered from a structural choice model, while the distribution of health risk is quantified with a professional risk assessment software program.

Preliminary results reveal lot of unraveling due to asymmetric information/adverse selection. One way to potentially reduce this unraveling is by allowing pricing based on pre-existing conditions, which the PPACA bans. However, in the longer run, pricing pre-existing conditions can subject consumers to re-classification risk. The PIs will examine the effects of this rule. Preliminary results suggest the losses from reclassification risk may far outweigh the adverse selection losses. In addition, absent subsidies, around 20% of the population would opt out of the exchange in the absence of a mandate compelling participation. The PIs also propose to examine the impact of a number of possible alternative designs of an exchange. One of these is the current suggestions for risk adjustment, which has recently been proposed by HHS.

POR.DRECONTENT:
We have produced two successful research articles on health insurance market design as a result of the support provided by the National Science Foundation. This has been very visible research with a large set of substantive results. 

The first paper, titled "Equilibia in Health Insurance Exchanges: Adverse Selection vs. Reclassification Risk," was published in Econometrica, a leading journal in Economics, in July 2015. This research was presented at over 30 universities and academic conferences from 2012-2015, by myself and the other two project collaborators. This paper was recently rewarded the prestigious Frisch Medal given by the Econometric Society. This medal is generally considered one of the top 3 prizes an economist can receive, and is awarded to the best applied paper in Econometrica over the prior five year period. The award is given once every two years, and was awarded to this paper in April 2016. 

This paper studies the design and regulation of compeitive health insurance markets. It specifically investigates insurer pricing regulation, with an emphasis on how much insurers can vary premiums as a function of enrollee health risk. The work investigates a tradeoff between adverse selection that results from community rating (charging everyone the same price) and reclassification that results when consumers can be charged different prices based on health status (they face lifetime risk of year to year premium changes). The work studies many complementary regulations, such as risk-adjustment transfers and the individual mandate, and presents welfare analysis to assess when distinct types of regulations are better or worse.  

The second paper, is a complete working paper which is still research in progress. This paper is titled "The Welfare Effects of Dynamic Health Insurance Contracts" and has been presented at approximately 10 research universities and academic conferences already, though it is still work in progress. This paper is likely to be a complete NBER working paper within the next six months, and published within the next several years.

It is a nice complement to the first paper from a research standpoint, and specifically investigates regulation related to how long insurance contracts are allowed to be. It specifically studies dynamic insurance contracts, and assesses how they can improve welfare by decreasing the reclassification risk studied in the first paper.
